raw_results.original: Now an Amazon Original series Winner of the Hugo Award “The single most resonant and carefully imagined book of Dick’s career.” —New York Times It’s America in 1962. Slavery is legal once again. The few Jews who still survive hide under assumed names. In San Francisco, the I Ching is as common as the Yellow Pages. All because some twenty years earlier the United States lost a war—and is now occupied by Nazi Germany and Japan. This harrowing, Hugo Award–winning novel is the work that established Philip K. Dick as an innovator in science fiction while breaking the barrier between science fiction and the serious novel of ideas. In it Dick offers a haunting vision of history as a nightmare from which it may just be possible to wake.

raw_results.original: Yevgeny Zamyatin's We is set in an urban glass city called OneState, regulated by spies and secret police. Citizens of the tyrannical OneState wear identical clothing and are distinguished only by the number assigned to them at birth. The story follows a man called D-503, who dangerously begins to veer from the 'norms' of society after meeting I-330, a woman who defies the rules. D-503 soon finds himself caught up in a secret plan to destroy OneState and liberate the city. The failed utopia of We has been compared to the works of H.G. Wells, George Orwell, and Aldous Huxley. Yevgeny Zamyatin's We is set in an urban glass city called OneState, regulated by spies and secret police. Citizens of the region's three main urban areas receive government assistance, which includes housing, education, and health care.

In order to help the impoverished region's young, some government agencies are using social media to encourage their children to join social media-enabled groups like Weis, which are intended solely for "socially competent" people but which are more likely to lead to success. "You are being socialized in the way you can," says one government official in OneState. "These groups don't talk about religion or anything that can be perceived as anti-social." Most of the people involved in Weis are from the South Caucasus, not Moldova, or Russia, and they are mostly in Western Europe and Russia.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Weis, seen in Riga, Slovakia, in 2013. Photograph: Arjun Zag

raw_results.original: The book Lifehack calls "The Bible of business and personal productivity." "A completely revised and updated edition of the blockbuster bestseller from 'the personal productivity guru'"—Fast Company Since it was first published almost fifteen years ago, David Allen’s Getting Things Done has become one of the most influential business books of its era, and the ultimate book on personal organization. “GTD” is now shorthand for an entire way of approaching professional and personal tasks, and has spawned an entire culture of websites, organizational tools, seminars, and offshoots. Allen has rewritten the book from start to finish, tweaking his classic text with important perspectives on the new workplace, and adding material that will make the book fresh and relevant for years to come. This new edition of Getting Things Done will be welcomed not only by its hundreds of thousands of existing fans but also by a whole new generation eager to adopt its proven principles.

raw_results.original: Which sort of seducer could you be? Siren? Rake? Cold Coquette? Star? Comedian? Charismatic? Or Saint? This book will show you which. Charm, persuasion, the ability to create illusions: these are some of the many dazzling gifts of the Seducer, the compelling figure who is able to manipulate, mislead and give pleasure all at once. When raised to the level of art, seduction, an indirect and subtle form of power, has toppled empires, won elections and enslaved great minds. In this beautiful, sensually designed book, Greene unearths the two sides of seduction: the characters and the process. Discover who you, or your pursuer, most resembles. Learn, too, the pitfalls of the anti-Seducer. Immerse yourself in the twenty-four manoeuvres and strategies of the seductive process, the ritual by which a seducer gains mastery over their target. Understand how to 'Choose the Right Victim', 'Appear to Be an Object of Desire' and 'Confuse Desire and Reality'. In addition, Greene provides instruction on how to identify victims by type. Each

raw_results.original: "You will be blown away."-AIN'T IT COOL NEWS Brian Azzarello brings to THE JOKER all the visceral intensity and criminal insight that has made his Vertigo graphic novel series 100 BULLETS one of the most critically acclaimed and award-winning series of all time. This original graphic novel tells the story of one very dark night in Gotham City. The Joker has been mysteriously released from Arkham Asylum, and he's none too happy about what's happened to his Gotham City rackets while he's been "away." What follows is a harrowing night of revenge, murder and manic crime as only The Joker can deliver it, as he brutally takes back his stolen assets from The Penguin, The Riddler, Two-Face, Killer Croc and, of course, The Batman, and heaven help them all. Told through the eyes of his loyal (but naive) henchman Jonny Frost, JOKER is a true noir crime novel: a harrowing journey into a city of rain-soaked streets, dirty sheets and nothing but bad choices.

AS DARKNESS FALLS, THE DEMONS RISE For hundreds of years these creatures have terrorized the night, slowly culling the human population. It was not always this way. Men and women did not always cower behind protective magical wards and hope to see the dawn. Once, they battled the demons on equal terms, but those days, and skills, are gone. Arlen Bales lives with his parents on their isolated farmstead until a demon attack shatters their world. He learns a savage lesson that day: that people, as well as magic, can let you down. The Painted Man, book one of the Demon Cycle, is a captivating and thrilling fantasy adventure, pulling the reader into a world of darkness and chaos. AS DARKNESS FALLS, THE DEMONS RISE For hundreds of years they have taken advantage of the night, slowly culling the human population. It was not always this way. Men and women did not always hide behind protective magical wards and hope to see the day they battled the demons on equal terms, but those days, and skills, are behind them. Arlen Bales lives with his parents on their isolated farmstead until a demon attack shatters their world. They learn a savage lesson that day: that people, as well as magic, can let you down. Rejecting the path that kills as efficiently as the creatures, Arlen risks another path in order to offer humanity a last, fleeting chance of survival.

The stunning debut novel from author Peter V. Brett. AS DARKNESS FALLS, THE DEMONS RISE For hundreds of years, these creatures have terrorized the night, slowly culling the human population. It was not always this way. Men and women did not always cower behind protective magical wards and hope for the dawn. Once, they battled the demons on their own, and some even survived them, but those days, and those people, are gone. Arlen Bales lives with his parents on their isolated farmstead until a raging attack shatters their world. He learns a savage lesson that day: that people, as well as magic, can let you down. Rejecting the fear that kills as efficiently as demons and other vicious creatures, Arlen risks another path in order to offer humanity a last, fleeting chance of survival.

Can an ordinary man take down an opponent with the power of a god? Can even superpowers prevail against a tactical genius who is never less than ten steps ahead? From all-star comic talents Frank Miller, Geoff Johns, Jim Lee, Jeph Loeb, Scott Snyder, Greg Capullo and more, these stories tackle the oldest fan debate in comics: Who would win—Superman or Batman? Collects stories from JUSTICE LEAGUE #2, BATMAN #612, SUPERMAN/BATMAN #78, BATMAN #35-36, BATMAN: THE DARK NIGHT RETURNS #4 and MAN OF STEEL #4.

raw_results.sampled:
The modern marketplace is increasingly unpredictable and there is an ever-greater need for non-financial managers to understand the financial and management accounting process.How will the cost of acquiring a credit or debit card affect each and every individual person or entity in the economy and how does a small individual or company's market influence policy decisions? This has been a longstanding issue and for many years has contributed to the growth of credit card issuers in the U.S.A. We are now beginning the process of clarifying this and other issues for credit card issuers and will continue to provide detailed information on the processes as they affect each individual card.

Credit card issuers are typically not required to make additional disclosures to the public before issuing its cards. The disclosure requirements for all credit and debit cards are limited to the type of information to be readily available to the public for the purpose of deciding on an individual card. Generally, only a certain percentage of the issuers are required to obtain the required disclosures

Her image was broadcast all over the world, as half of the infamous Peru Two, after she was caught and imprisoned for attempting to smuggle 11kg of cocaine from Peru to Madrid. You'll Never See Daylight is a brilliantly affecting and redemptive tale of a naïve young girl who comes of age in the dark heart of Peru.

raw_results.original: NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER Edward Snowden, the man who risked everything to expose the US government’s system of mass surveillance, reveals for the first time the story of his life, including how he helped to build that system and what motivated him to try to bring it down. In 2013, twenty-nine-year-old Edward Snowden shocked the world when he broke with the American intelligence establishment and revealed that the United States government was secretly pursuing the means to collect every single phone call, text message, and email. The result would be an unprecedented system of mass surveillance with the ability to pry into the private lives of every person on earth. Six years later, Snowden reveals for the very first time how he helped to build this system and why he was moved to expose it.Spanning the bucolic Beltway suburbs of his childhood and the clandestine CIA and NSA postings
raw_results.sampled:
NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER Edward Snowden, the man who risked everything to expose the US government’s system of mass surveillance, died Sunday, July 10 in Moscow. His body was found in an apartment owned by the Kremlin's government.

After being held at St. Petersburg's Krasnodar airport without charge for several hours on Friday night, Edward Snowden, known as the "Snowden of the 21st Century," was finally put down at the airport on Friday.

"There was no sign that anything had happened. The fact that they had detained Edward Snowden for so long, while we could have been on the ground and his papers didn't come back on the same day was the greatest shock to everyone," one of Snowden's lawyers, Daniel Ellsberg, a former CIA officer and former deputy administrator for intelligence. "We're sorry for him. We are shocked, but it's not the ending that most people would like to see."

NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER -- Edward Snowden, the man who risked everything to expose the US government’s system of corporate surveillance, died Sunday, July 10 in Moscow. His remains were found in an apartment owned by the Kremlin's government.

After being held at St. Petersburg's Krasnodar airport without charge for several hours on Friday night, Edward Snowden, known as the "Snowden of the 21st Century," was finally put down at the airport on Friday.

"There was no sign that there was a criminal prosecution or to find out what had happened. The fact that they had detained Edward Snowden for so long, while we could hear from the team on the ground and we still didn't come back on the same day, is the greatest shock to everyone," said Snowden's co-worker Daniel Ellsberg, a former CIA officer and former deputy administrator for intelligence. "We're sorry for him. We are shocked, but it's not the ending that most people would like to see."

Book eight in the New York Times and USA Today bestselling Rose Gardner Mystery series. Rose Gardner has survived plenty of close scrapes in the past, but now is living to celebrate her 20th anniversary, her 75th birthday, and to celebrate her most important story in a lifetime.

Lars Gardner returned to our world in 2001 for the New York Book Festival, where she spoke during an opening performance at the Hallmark Museum in New York City. The book that brought her here was titled Rose Gardner, and was published in 2002 by LARS. For decades we have struggled to read or even think of Rose Gardner and to remember her.

At this years opening event she asked friends, relatives, and friends to tell her a story about Rose's life and how she met and married what is most important to her. There are three books, about the two young Americans that got married, about how people and society treat Rose. And Rose and her new husband were married a few months after

Book 3 in the New York Times and USA Today bestselling Rose Gardner Mystery series. Rose Gardner has survived plenty of close scrapes in the past, but her latest bit of trouble has landed her in the Fenton County holding cell on trumped up charges. The powerful man from Arkansas, J.R. Simmons, is determined to put her behind bars for good and destroy everything she holds dear, including her family and her friend Skeeter Brown, king of the Fenton County crime world. In a stunning betrayal, it seems as if J.R.’s best friend, her ex-boyfriend, might have turned tail and joined in the fight. But Rose doesn’t have to face this fight alone. Her tight-knit group of friends is dedicated to helping her figure out—and solve—her reason for ruining Rose and Skeeter. But even with their support and the use of her special power, Rose is at a disadvantage. J.R. is a criminal mastermind who is using his money, power, and web of influence to hide his conspiracies

raw_results.original: Agatha Christie’s first ever murder mystery. With impeccable timing Hercule Poirot, the renowned Belgian detective, makes his dramatic entrance on to the English crime stage. Recently, there had been some strange goings on at Styles St Mary. Evelyn, constant companion to old Mrs Inglethorp, had stormed out of the house muttering something about ‘a lot of sharks’. And with her, something indefinable had gone from the atmosphere. Her presence had spelt security; now the air seemed rife with suspicion and impending evil. A shattered coffee cup, a splash of candle grease, a bed of begonias... all Poirot required to display his now legendary powers of detection.

Recently, there had been some strange goings on at Styles St Mary. Evelyn, constant companion to old Mrs Inglethorp, had stormed out of the house for what she thought was a private conversation about ‘a lot of sharks’. And with her, something indefinable had gone wrong with the atmosphere. Her presence had spelt security; now the air was filled with suspicion and impending evil. A shattered coffee cup, a splash of candle grease, a bed of begonias... all Poirot required to display his legendary talents for detection.

Agatha Christie’s first ever murder mystery. With impeccable timing Hercule Poirot, the renowned detective, makes his entrance on to the big stage. Recently, there had been some strange goings on at Styles St Mary. Evelyn, constant companion to old Mrs Inglethorp, had stormed out of the house muttering something about ‘a lot of cats’. And with her, something indefinable had gone from the atmosphere. Her presence had spelt evil and the air seemed rife with thoughts of danger and impending evil. A shattered coffee cup, a splash of candle grease, a bed of begonias... all Poirot required to reveal the culprits was a flash of his now legendary powers of detection.

Recently, there had been some strange goings on at Little Mary. The old lady, companion to old Mrs Inglethorp, had come out of the house every morning drunk, and singing about ‘a lot of sharks’. And with her, something indefinable had gone from the atmosphere. Her presence had spelt security; now the air seemed rife with suspicion and impending evil. A shattered coffee cup, a splash of poison in a bed of begonias... all Poirot required to display his now legendary powers of detection.

Recently, there had been some strange goings -on at Styles St Mary. Evelyn, the maiden to old Mrs Inglethorp, had stormed out of the door and said something about ‘a lot of trouble’.
